data.title: Mary J. Blige Is Still Hard, But Surprisingly Tender
data.meta_description: Her hardness is what sold her from the start. And it continues to sell her. So on her new album, "The Breakthrough," don't be fooled by the demure cover shot of Mary J. Blige. In the silver-toned picture, the Yonkers, N.Y., native seems peaceful. Ornate earrings kiss her shoulders. Her hair is parted and a thick, ropelike braid runs across the top of her head. The look is regal, and it fits. After all, Blige has been known as the "Queen of Hip-Hop Soul" since the release of her 1992 debut, "What's the 411?" On "The Breakthrough," her seventh album, she even brags about her hit-making status.</p> <p>Musically on the new CD, the singer-songwriter does what she has always done: melds the gospel fervor of classic soul with the synthetic beats of hip-hop. The formula, though, has worn a bit thin. Her last album, 2003's "Love &amp; Life," was boring, laden with rote grooves. The first half of "Breakthrough," unfortunately, continues that trend, but her vocals are fuller and more impassioned this time.</p> <p>Faceless tunes like the first single, "Be Without You," are listenable only because the hip-hop soul queen sounds emotionally invested. But the song isn't particularly memorable. "Gonna Breakthrough" is a run-of-the-mill club joint featuring Blige's rapping alter ego, whom she calls Brook.</p> <p>The 16-cut album becomes more engaging about midway through with "Good Woman Down," a mid-tempo anthem-like number for downtrodden sisters looking for a way out of abusive relationships. In "Take Me as I Am," Blige acknowledges the drama of her past and urges her lover (and fans) to accept her, scars and all.</p> <p>"Can't Hide From Luv," featuring Jay-Z, recalls the beat-heavy, feel-good vibe of such Blige classics as "Real Love" and "You Bring Me Joy." </p> <p>After that pointless cut, Blige delivers several stunning, creamy soul numbers that would have been at home on 1999's "Mary," the singer's most assured and consistent album to date. With its gentle guitars and swooning layered vocals, "Can't Get Enough" updates the softer side of classic Curtis Mayfield. </p> <p>"I Found My Everything," featuring the gifted Raphael Saadiq, marries the down-home churchiness of Candi Staton with the dramatic orchestral swells heard on Diana Ross' early solo records. The blissful song is magnificent, probably Blige's best performance committed to tape. But she returns to brutal emotional honesty on the self-penned "Father in You." The album ends with a sanctified version of U2's "One," a duet with Bono.</p> <p>"The Breakthrough" is an uneven album. But the songs on the latter half of the new CD reveal the singer's tremendous growth as an interpreter. Underneath Blige's steeliness is a pearl of a soul singer.</p>
data.text:
By Rashod D. Ollison, Baltimore Sun Her hardness is what sold her from the start. And it continues to sell her. So on her new album, "The Breakthrough," don't be fooled by the demure cover shot of Mary J. Blige. In the silver-toned picture, the Yonkers, N.Y., native seems peaceful. Ornate earrings kiss her shoulders. Her hair is parted and a thick, ropelike braid runs across the top of her head. The look is regal, and it fits. After all, Blige has been known as the "Queen of Hip-Hop Soul" since the release of her 1992 debut, "What's the 411?" On "The Breakthrough," her seventh album, she even brags about her hit-making status.

Musically on the new CD, the singer-songwriter does what she has always done: melds the gospel fervor of classic soul with the synthetic beats of hip-hop. The formula, though, has worn a bit thin. Her last album, 2003's "Love & Life," was boring, laden with rote grooves. The first half of "Breakthrough," unfortunately, continues that trend, but her vocals are fuller and more impassioned this time.

Faceless tunes like the first single, "Be Without You," are listenable only because the hip-hop soul queen sounds emotionally invested. But the song isn't particularly memorable. "Gonna Breakthrough" is a run-of-the-mill club joint featuring Blige's rapping alter ego, whom she calls Brook.

The 16-cut album becomes more engaging about midway through with "Good Woman Down," a mid-tempo anthem-like number for downtrodden sisters looking for a way out of abusive relationships. In "Take Me as I Am," Blige acknowledges the drama of her past and urges her lover (and fans) to accept her, scars and all.

"Can't Hide From Luv," featuring Jay-Z, recalls the beat-heavy, feel-good vibe of such Blige classics as "Real Love" and "You Bring Me Joy."

After that pointless cut, Blige delivers several stunning, creamy soul numbers that would have been at home on 1999's "Mary," the singer's most assured and consistent album to date. With its gentle guitars and swooning layered vocals, "Can't Get Enough" updates the softer side of classic Curtis Mayfield.

"I Found My Everything," featuring the gifted Raphael Saadiq, marries the down-home churchiness of Candi Staton with the dramatic orchestral swells heard on Diana Ross' early solo records. The blissful song is magnificent, probably Blige's best performance committed to tape. But she returns to brutal emotional honesty on the self-penned "Father in You." The album ends with a sanctified version of U2's "One," a duet with Bono.

"The Breakthrough" is an uneven album. But the songs on the latter half of the new CD reveal the singer's tremendous growth as an interpreter. Underneath Blige's steeliness is a pearl of a soul singer.
